description:
Overview

"52 Pick-Up" concludes as Booster Gold journeys back in time to save the best friend he ever had - the Blue Beetle! But can Booster stop Maxwell Lord before someone else dies in Ted Kord's place? And will Ted Kord let that happen?

Summary

Dan Garrent, the orginal Blue Beetle, James Reyes, the current Blue Beetle and the Blue Beetle of the future convice Booster Gold that to save the universe they need to stop the murder of Ted Kord. The four heros leave Rip Hunter to repair Skeet and travel to the past to save Ted.

While in the time bubble Booster tell the others all about Ted and the great things he's done.

Meanwhile back in the present in Pittsburg Daniel and Rose exchange lies they told and are about to embrace when Rip Hunter intreupt and presents them with two costumes.

Back in the past, Ted is about to be murdered by Max Lord when Booster and the three other beetles bust in. A fight insues and Max releases an Omac, but the three beetle together are able to stop it.

They save Ted and the beetle of the future sends all of Max's plans to Batman.

They return to there own time with the cautionary tale that Ted must appear dead for the time line to surrive.
name: 52 Pick-Up, Chapter 6: Meet The Beetles

description:
Mysteries, mayhem and music abound at the house that Scooby built...the opera house, that is!

Plus, there's something strange happening in a little town called Vladsburg!
name: Ghouls Night At The Opera; A Town Called Vladsburg!

description:
Overview

They said it would be a cold day in Hell before Groo did something intelligent. Well, he didn't, but it is anyway. Icebergs are melting or going south for the winter. Volcanoes are erupting. Rains are raining. It's starting to look like the end of the world and amazingly, it isn't Groo's fault. (Well, some of it is.) Blame the award-winning team of Sergio Aragonés and Mark Evanier, along with letterer Stan Sakai and colorist Tom Luth. That's right: the same guys who've been doing Groo for a quarter of a century. Sooner or later, they're bound to get it right.

A brand-new super-menace enters Spider-Girl’s life when she crosses paths with Deadspot—the invisible destroyer who kills with a touch!

A world class assassin has been hired to kill Spider-Girl. Spider-Girl has been busy trying to locate Daniel Kingsley in the hopes of getting a lead on his brother, the Hobgoblin.

As May and Mary Jane prepare for school (it's Mary Jane's first day as a counselor at Midtown High. When May gets a moment with her father, she tells him that Benjy has shown some signs of developing spider-powers. They decide to not tell Mary Jane just yet because she has too many other things to worry about. On their walk to school, May's spider-senses go off. She doesn't want to worry her mother and since she's not detecting a huge danger, she doesn't try to locate the source.

Black Tarantula talks to Chesbro over the phone. It appears that Black Tarantula is the one that hired Deadspot to kill Spider-Girl. He says it's her own fault since she's messed with his business so many times.

At school, May continues to get buzzes from her spider-senses. Running into Gene, he tells her that he misses her and wishes they could get back together. This leaves May speechless.

Mindworm discovers that someone has offered Fancy Dan the secret Wilson Fisk files. Hobgoblin is outraged because Spider-Girl told him she destroyed the file. Hobgoblin calls Detective Drasco telling him he has to get a hold of the file for him. Drasco smiles since Spider-Girl trusted him with the files, thinking he was a completely honest cop.

Back at Midtown, May continues to feel as if she's getting stalked. Her cell phone goes off. Chesbro tells her her life is in danger and that an assassin is after her. Going to see him, Chesbro gives her a file on Deadspot. The file isn't too informative as Deadspot does not want a lot of information to be known. Spider-Girl leaves and Deadspot reveals herself to Chesbro. She demands the file and who his source is so she can deal with them. She says that he has become a liability to Black Tarantula also. Chesbro asks if she's going to kill him if she could tell him who hired her. As she's about to reveal the name, Spider-Girl returns by smashing through the window. Using her spider-senses, she is able to duck and hit Deadspot even when she uses her invisiblity.

Deadspot escapes and the stalker is revealed to have a Midtown High backpack.
name: Broken Bonds

description:
Overview

THE SEVEN CAPITAL CITIES OF HEAVEN continues ever onwards. The kicking intensifies. The mysteries intensify. And the answers Danny Rand has so desperately sought begin coming faster and faster. What if he's been asking the wrong questions all this time? What does Hydra have planned for the mystical city of K'un-Lun? Who is the Prince of Orphans, and what is his connection to the Randall fortune? How can Danny stop an army on Earth when he's being forced to fight in a heavenly kung fu tournament? Read the book ENTERTAINMENT WEEKLY gives an A- and calls a MUST!
name: The Seven Capital Cities of Heaven, Part 5

story_arc_credits.name: The Seven Capital Cities of Heaven

first_appearance_storyarcs.name: The Seven Capital Cities of Heaven

description:
The formation of the Squad is revealed in this issue, as Hardcase, Starburst, D.J. Blast and Forsa gain their ultra powers and show them to the media. The public recognition unites the four people to advance their careers and to do some good in the world. Meanwhile, other people discover their ultra abilities but are able to keep out of the public eye. Meanwhile, Rex Mundi has his eyes on the four members of the Squad and informs NM-E that it needs to destroy them.

In a backup story, Mantra and her daughter Evie go to a ceremony honoring Starburst, who remains in a coma. Mantra takes Evie to see Starburst in the hospital room when a mad woman enters the hospital room with a bomb attached to her chest. She explains that her son, a police officer, was killed by NM-E in the same battle that devastated the Squad but gets no recognition. Mantra stops the woman before she can hurt anyone.
name: The Hard Way

volume.name: Ultraverse Year Zero: The Death Of The Squad

description: While Bruce Lee demonstrated his Jeet Kune Do in the movies, DC produced a new series featuring martial arts expert Richard Dragon. Richard Dragon, Kung Fu Fighter was based on the 1974 novel Dragon Fists by "Jim Dennis" (the shared pseudonym of comic book writer Denny O'Neil and artist Jim Berry). With art by Leo Duranona, the series adapted Dragon's origins - as a young thief, reformed to train in the martial arts - for the DC universe.
name: Coming of a Dragon

description: Writer Denny O'Neil and artist Ric Estrada matched up martial arts her Richard Dragon with dangerous beauty Lady Shiva in January. Naming herself after the Hindu goddess of destruction, Shiva was once Sandra Woosan, whose sister Carolyn had been killed while under Dragon's protection. Criminal businessman and arch enemy of Dragon,Guano Cravat, convinced Shiva the Dragon was Carolyn's murderer, even though one of his own lieutenants had actually committed the foul deed. Shiva demonstrated her killer martial arts skills in battle with Dragon, until he convinced her of his innocence nad helped her take down Cravat.
name: The Arean of No Exit

description:
Overview

The Joker. The Rogues. The Cheetah. And they're just the beginning of Catwoman's problems.

The world's most violent and dangerous villains have been sent to the Hell Planet from SALVATION RUN, and Catwoman's just arrived! Selina Kyle's got skills, cunning and craftiness, but she's also going to need to make a deal with the devil in order to stay alive!
name: Waking Up On The Wrong Side Of The Universe, Part 1

description: Plagued by dark visions of the demon Jei, Priest Senzo creates an uproar in the temple when his terrifying dreams intensify. Elsewhere, the hunt for Inazuma, killer of Boss Bakuchi's son, reaches a tipping point. A group of bounty hunters have cornered her in a peasant's hut, but they aren't the only hunters on Inazuma's trail. Together with Gen and Stray Dog, Usagi finds his way to the hut--yet what the three discover upon arrival defies description!
name: Sparrows, Chapter Three

description:
1. Cover by Kurt Schaffenberger.
  2. "Will the Real Superman Please Show Up?" written by Cary Bates, penciled by Kurt Schaffenberger, inked by Tex Blaisdell, colored by Jerry Serpe and lettered by Morris Waldinger.
  3. "Daily Planet" Volume 77 Issue 22 the week of May 30, 1977 edited by Bob Rozakis, production by Anthony Tollin and lettered by Typeset. Featuring "Batman Murdered!!". Plus, "Ask the Answer Man".
  4. "One for the Money!" A "The Private Life of Clark Kent" story written by Bob Toomey, penciled by Kurt Schaffenberger, inked by Tex Blaisdell and colored by Jerry Serpe. Clark buys a winning lottery ticket.

Notes:

  • The first issue that began to credit the letterer.
name: Will the Real Superman Please Show Up? / One for the Money!

description: Michelangelo encounters anachronistic sorcery when trying to write his novel. Inspired by a panel from TMNT vol.4 Issue #18
name: Circle of Darkness / The Mother of All Anger

description: Casey, April and Shadow go to an alien impressionist's show where Jones comes face to face with his nightmare self/
name: Reflections

description:
Superman, Batman and Robin chase a wanted felon into a cave, where they are mysteriously transported 1,000 years into the future and have to fight a descendant of Luthor!

  1. Teddy Roosevelt: Guardian of Nature (biographical strip / written by Jack Schiff)
  2. The Three Super-Sleepers (Superman, Batman and Robin / written by Edmond Hamilton)
  3. Broadway Laffs (gag strip)
  4. The Chain Letter Arrows (Green Arrow, Speedy / written by Ed Herron)
  5. How to Trace Your Family Tree (full text article)
  6. Sagebrush Sam (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  7. Jerry the Jitterbug gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  8. The Teller of Tall Tales (Tomahawk / written by Dave Wood)

"Superman, Batman, and Robin-- those great heroes of the past! But this is the year 2957--they've been in suspended animation for 1,000 years!
name: The Three Super-Sleepers

description:
1. Cover by Rich Buckler and Bob Oksner.
  2. "Earth's Last Day!" written by Gerry Conway, penciled by Curt Swan, inked by Francisco Chiaramonte, colored by Jerry Serpe and lettered by Clem Robins. Guest appearances by Bruce Wayne and Alfred Pennyworth.
  3. "DC Publishorial" "It's a Mystery..." 3/4 page text piece by Jenette Kahn.
  4. "DC Profiles #24 Larry Hama" 1/4 page text piece by Unknown.

Notes:

  • This issue contains the Hostess Superhero Ad, the Penguin in "The Cuckoo Cuckoos".
name: Earth's Last Day!

description:
1. Cover by Kurt Schaffenberger.
  2. "The Attack of the Anti-Super-Hero" written by Cary Bates, penciled by Kurt Schaffenberger, inked by Vince Colletta, colored by Jerry Serpe and lettered by Milt Snapinn.
  3. "DC Publishorial" "Whatever Happened to ..? (Fill in Your Favorite Cancelled Title)" 3/4 page text piece by Jenette Kahn.
  4. "DC Profiles #20 Neal Adams" 1/4 page text piece by Unknown.

Notes:

  • This issue contains the Hostess Superhero Ad, Wonder Woman in "Cooky La Moo on Broadway".
name: The Attack of the Anti-Super-Hero

description:
1. 'Black Magic On Mars'
  2. 'The People Vs. Superman' (Superman vs Ace / written by Al Schwartz)
  3. 'Pioneer Days In Oregon'
  4. 'How Football Began' (full text article)
  5. 'Mr. Mxyztplk, Hero' (Superman vs Mr. Mxyztplk / written by Al Schwartz)
 
'Black Magic on Mars' - Following a morning of shooting on the film 'Black Magic' in Italy, Orson Welles and actress Nancy Guild drive through the mountains to a masquerade ball, they discover a rocket ship. Orson climbs aboard and is whisked off to Mars where he learns about a Martian invasion of earth. He uses the equipment to broadcast a warning to Earth, but nobody believes him thanks to his infamous 'War of the Worlds' broadcast. No one that is, except for Superman!
name: Black Magic on Mars

description:
1. Cover by Neal Adams.
  2. "Superman... Guilty of Homicide!" written by Leo Dorfman, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by George Klein.
  3. "Superboy in Argo City" written by Cary Bates, penciled and inked by Jim Mooney.

Can Superman really have killed?
name: Superman... Guilty of Homicide! / Superboy in Argo City

description:
The Squad decide to test and train their special abilities before going public. When D.J. Blast informs the rest of the Squad that he wants to take down gang violence in his community, the others agree to help him. Before they can do anything, the gang in his neighborhood kidnap D.J. Blast's girlfriend and sister. The Squad goes to the gang's hideout and rescues the two women and hurting many gang members in the process. The police arrive at the scene and arrest the Squad for being vigilantes. However, the mayor and the chief of police talk to them and tell them they could fight crime under their jurisdiction. That's when the Squad goes public. They receives a plethora of fan-mail and one letter prompts Hardcase to reprimand a man who beats his wife. After that, Hardcase and Starburst share their mutual attraction to each other. It was with Starburst that Hardcase finds out the man he reprimanded killed his wife and children, much to his guilt.

In a backup story, Rune hunts and kills a man who hunts ultrahumans.
name: The New Sensation

volume.name: Ultraverse Year Zero: The Death Of The Squad

description:
The Rodney King trial is coming to its conclusion and the Squad are feeling nervous about its impact. When the defendants of the trial are found innocent, Los Angeles goes into a riot. However, the Squad are told by police personnel that they are not allowed to get involved. The Squad defies that order and goes to the streets to help, but they find their efforts fruitless. In the middle of the riots, a man with the ultra power to generate electricity uses his ability to defend his uncle's store, accidentally killing one of the rioters. The riots finally die down and a police officer, Jamal Brown, tells the Squad that their efforts helped more than they could realize.

In a backup story, Firearm is on a mission in New York City.
name: City On Fire

volume.name: Ultraverse Year Zero: The Death Of The Squad

description:
1. "The Case of the People against Superman!" (Superman) written by Leo Dorfman, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by George Klein.
  2. "The Super-Initiation of Supergirl!" (Supergirl) written by Otto Binder, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger.
name: The Case of the People against Superman! / The Super-Initiation of Supergirl!

description:
1. Cover by Wayne Boring and Kurt Schaffenberger.
  2. "The Demon in the Bottle!" (part 1) "The Double-Crossing Demon!" (part 2) written by Leo Dorfman, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger.

Notes:

  • Story continues in the next issue.

Vitar: Release me, fair mortal, and my black magic will grant you every wish!"

Superman: Lois! Don't fall for his line...he's trying to trick you into taking his place in the bottle!
name: The Demon in the Bottle!

description: There are a slew of murders in Los Angeles and the police believe each victim was an ultra that remained to stay out of the public's view. The Squad are told this information and stay alert for the killer. Meanwhile, the government wants the Squad to work for them but the Squad denies them. While at Forsa's housewarming party the ultra killer, NM-E, attacks. NM-E is able to kill every non-ultra in the house before the Squad is able to suitably attack. Forsa sends NM-E into a nearby aqueduct where the battle concludes. NM-E kills Forsa and knocks Starburst into a coma. Before D.J. Blast is killed by the monster, he tells Hardcase to take Starburst and to get away. Hardcase jumps in the air with Starburst in his arms when D.J. Burst sacrifices himself to destroy the monster. The Squad has died.
name: End Of The Innocents

volume.name: Ultraverse Year Zero: The Death Of The Squad

description:
1. Cover by Neal Adams.
  2. "The Head of Hate!" written by Leo Dorfman, penciled by Ross Andru and inked by Mike Esposito.
  3. "The 40th Century Outlaw!" written by Otto Binder, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger.
name: The Head of Hate! / The 40th Century Outlaw!

description: The fury...the beauty...the battle! An apocalyptic scene of burning Tokyo streets is the meeting place for this blood war. Wolverine questions the judgement and perhaps lost goals of Shi that have placed her in a situation most desperate. Questions that inflame an already internal wound of the soul that Shi is fighting within herself. The overused term, "battle to the death," has become tired and worn out. The battle that that Tucci and Smith inject Wolverine and Shi into deals with more than the bloodshed of a physical plane. It delves into the souls of these two warriors of legend as they battle for more than just life. They battle for the right to die on their own terms. This prequel of the new "Judgement Night" series sets the stage for only one to walk away. And only one will.
name: Dark Night of Judgment

description:
1. Cover by Neal Adams.
  2. "The Leper from Krypton!" written by Leo Dorfman, penciled by Ross Andru and inked by Mike Esposito.
  3. "The Landmark Looters!" written by Otto Binder, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger.
name: The Leper from Krypton! / The Landmark Looters!

description:
1. Home, Sweet Home! (public service message by Binky / written by Jack Schiff) -- 2. The Giant Who Came to Smallville! (Superboy, Lana Lang, Ma and Pa Kent) -- 3. Jerry the Jitterbug (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff) -- 4. The Picture that Stopped Superboy! (Superboy, Lana / written by William Woolfolk) -- 5. Quick Quiz -- 6. Peg (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff) -- 7. Raising the "Q" Flag (full text article) -- 8. Tommy Tuttle - Superboy's Pal! (Superboy / written by Bill Finger)

Compare this cover to the July 1940 cover of "Thrilling Wonder Stories"
name: The Giant Who Came to Smallville
Gene Autry, Raiders of the Range
The Untouchable from Krypton / The Kiss of Death!
Substitute Superman

description:
1. "Jimmy Olsen, Cub Inventor" (Jimmy Olsen, Superman / written by Otto Binder)
  2. "Little Pete" (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  3. "The Million Dollar Question!" (Jimmy, Superman, Lex Luthor (flashback), Toyman (flashback), Prankster (flashback) written by Otto Binder, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by George Klein. Reprinted in The Superman Family #174.
  4. "Sagebrush Sam" (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  5. "Taste with a Twist" (full text article)
  6. "The Missile of Steel" (Jimmy, Superman, Superman robot / written by Otto Binder)

Jimmy Olsen: Controlling this robot of Superman is almost like being Superman himself!
name: Jimmy Olsen, Cub Inventor / The Million Dollar Question! / The Missile of Steel

description:
1. Cover by Neal Adams.
  2. "Mysteries of the Superman Awards!" (Superman) written by Otto Binder, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by George Klein.
  3. "Supergirl Battles the Evil of Alpha and Beta" (Supergirl) written by Cary Bates, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger.
name: Mysteries of the Superman Awards! / Supergirl Battles the Evil of Alpha and Beta

description: After seven books that have ranged from tragedy (Hey, Wait...) to drama (Sshhhh!) to thriller melodrama (The Iron Wagon, Why Are You Doing This?), Jason unleashes his inner Scandinavian goofball with this big collection of hilarious shorter pieces. God, the Devil, mummies, vampires, zombies, werewolves, reanimated skeletons, space invaders, Death, cavemen, Godzilla and Elvis populate these most often wordless blackout gags, side by side with Jason's usual Little-Orphan-Annie-eyed, rabbit-and-bird-head protagonists — a "lighter side" of one of the best cartoonists of the new millennium.

1. Cover by Carmine Infantino.
  2. "The Unemployed Superman!" (Superman) written by Otto Binder, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by Jack Abel.
  3. "Supergirl's Stand to Save Stanhope!" (Supergirl) written by Cary Bates, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger.
name: The Unemployed Superman! / Supergirl's Stand to Save Stanhope!

description:
Overview

Written by Scott Beatty with Christos Gage; Art by Wes Craig; Cover by Ivan Reis & Richard Friend

Exploding out of the pages of WildStorm Armageddon comes a biweekly 6-part adventure to save the WildStorm Universe by writers Scott Beatty (BATGIRL: YEAR ONE) & Christos Gage (STORMWATCH: PHD, WILDSTORM ARMAGEDDON) and rising-star artist Wes Craig (TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE)!

The rogue Coda warrior Nemesis, following her harrowing post-apocalyptic vision, must find Backlash and Savant to help her unlock the secrets of the coming destruction. But can anything stem the tide of darkness? Step one to fitting together the pieces of the intricate puzzle: infiltrate the world's most powerful and influential super-humans' headquarters and raid their database!
name: Revelations Part Two: Bleeding Hearts or...I Fight The Authority and The Authority Always Wins

description:
Remembering when he fought Superboy-Prime, how he lost his powers by going through a red sun. And being told he has lost his powers permanently. While walking through the streets of Metropolis.

But that was then and this is now...

He is still fighting Bloodsport, riot, Silver Banshee in the streets. From gaining his powers back in previous issues, but he feels that his powers have grow a bit, even astonishing him.

Battling had finished with the others, now still getting used to his powers.

Flying around Metropolis, Superman senses something. Ice starts to rise from the ground, but is this really Ice? And what does Lex Luthor have to do with it?
name: Up, Up, and Away! Part 7: Up in the Sky

description:
With the return of new series writer Chuck Dixon (ROBIN, NIGHTWING, BATMAN) and art by fan-favorite Chris Batista (52, LEGION OF SUPERHEROES), Robin #170 is the start of a new era no one will want to miss! After a life-changing battle with Ra's al Ghul in Nanda Parbat, Robin comes home to Gotham to find there's a new girl in town, wearing a color he can't ignore. The new vigilante calls herself Violet, and she steals from the rich to keep for herself...and Robin's going to find out that's not all she's playing for. Plus, the return of an old friend with something to hide!

In a warehouse, a "business deal" is going down until it is interrupted by a new female vigilante. When all the men are beat, the guy in charge tells her there isn't anything she can do. She can't prove anything. She just calls him a "silly silly man" and takes all the money. He tells all this to Batman and Robin. The man yells and ask if she was "one of them" why did she just take the money. There's supposed to be "rules." Batman says she must be working in a gray area and the man corrects him and says "violet." She was dressed in purple. This makes Tim think of Stephanie. When he tries talking to Batman, he just says that they both warned her of the dangers of being Spoiler. He tells Tim you have to accept your losses and move on. He suggests he get home since he has school tomorrow.

The next day at school, Tim is still thinking about Stephanie. He thinks how she didn't even get a memorial in the Cave. Caught daydreaming in class, he is put on the spot to answer a question. When he stumbles, another student asks if he can answer. Tim recognizes the voice and is overjoyed to see his old best friend, Ives, sitting behind him.

Tim introduces Ives to his (sometimes) girlfriend Zo. Tim asks his what happened with the homeschooling since he was transfered to this school. Ives says he was driving his mom crazy and makes a quick exit. Tim is suspicious because he knows Ives' mom loved homeschooling him.

At the police station, the man arrested earlier is placed in a holding room and told he has a visitor. He thinks it's his lawyer but it turns out to be Robin. He asks him about the money and figures that this wasn't the first time money was taken. The man confirms this. Robin asks for another exchange of money to try to catch the vigilante. The man asks what he'd get in return. Robing tells him he won't get a visit from his "big scary pal."

The next drop is set to take place at a bowling alley. Robin waits and waits and is beginning to get tired. He eventually falls asleep only to be awoken by the girl in purple. She asks him what he's supposed to be and tells him she's working this place. Surprised, he says, "It's you, the one in violet." She then says that is her name. They begin fighting and fall through the ceiling into the bowling alley. She asks herself who he's supposed to be. Robin says he'll be a friend if she'll let him. She sprays him in the face with mace (his mask protects him) and punches him to the ground.

The next day, Tim is left trying to explain how he got a black eye when he was supposed to be studying at the library the night before. He tells Zo and Randi that he was messing around on a skateboard and wiped out. As they walk away, Tim sees a familiar blond walk by. He tells himself it's not just the hair but also the way she walks. He tries following her but loses her in the stairway. He figures it must be because he has Stephanie on his mind and that Violet reminded him of her.

At the police station, the criminal makes bail. He's picked up by the boss' men. He's never met him before. To his shock, he discovers it is the Penguin and he's not too happy with what has happened. He tells him to bring Robin and the female to him or he'll end up dead like the two other men that had their money taken away.
name: The Fix

description: Peter Parker's gotta hustle if he's going to make it across town for his study date with Liz Allen! The good news? When you're secretly Spider-Man, city travel's a breeze. The not-so-good news? When you're in your Spidey costume, guys like Scorpion come outta the woodwork!
name: Rush Hour!

description:
While the women get to know each other, the Seven Deadly Sins are released from Pandora's Box.

variantcoverltdrelease date
Bad OddsRafa Lopez1000July 2006

volume.name: Brian Pulido's Lady Death: Lost Souls

description: Doctor Doom has finally set the stage for a plot to destroy his most hated enemies! (Hint: There’s four of them, and they’re fantastic.) But there’s one little red-and-blue flaw in his plan he has to do away with first! (Hint: It’s Spider-Man. Sheesh, couldn’t you figure that one out?) Rising-star artist Mike Norton joins his Gravity cohort, EISNER AWARD WINNER SEAN McKEEVER for the all-new, all-ages, all-action fun!
name: Doom with a View!; Franklin Richards, Son of a Genius: Weather or Not!

description: There's a new sensation on the New York City stage--and his name is Mysterio! Could it be that one of Spidey's greatest foes has gone legit? Or does the master of illusion have yet another trick up his sleeve? Also featuring the riveting return of fellow photog Andy Anderson!
name: Make Mine Mysterio!

description:
The games of the Crimson Ring are over, and the team of Lo'Gosh has lost a member, when Rehgar sold Valeera to other team.

While Broll and Lo'Gosh are planning to escape, a masked man appears and he seems to know something about Lo'Gosh past.
name: Destiny Awaits

description:
1. Cover by Curt Swan and Neal Adams.
  2. "The Great Phantom Peril!" written by Cary Bates, penciled by Curt Swan, inked by Tex Blaisdell and colored by Jerry Serpe. What happens when the Phantom Zone prisoners and the people of Earth switch places?
  3. "DC Publishorial" "Remembering the Five-Cent Phone Call?" 3/4 page text piece by Jenette Kahn.
  4. "DC Profiles #13 Paul Levitz" 1/4 page text piece by Mike Gold.

Notes:

  • This issue contains the Hostess Superhero Ad, Batman and Robin in "Birds of a Feather".
name: The Great Phantom Peril!

description:
1. Cover by Bob Oksner.
  2. "The Phantom Touch of Death!" written by Cary Bates, penciled by Curt Swan, inked by Tex Blaisdell and colored by Jerry Serpe.
  3. "Daily Planet" Volume 77 Issue 13 the week of March 28, 1977 edited by Bob Rozakis, production by Anthony Tollin and lettered by Typeset. Featuring the origin of the Justice League of America. Plus, "Ask the Answer Man" and the answers to Mini-Puzzle #2.
  4. "If I'm Here... What Am I Doing Over There?" A "The Sporting Life of Steve Lombard" story written by Bill Kunkel, penciled by John Calnan and inked by Tex Blaisdell.

Notes:

  • This issue contains the Hostess Superhero Ad, Batman and Robin in "Birds of a Feather".
  • The "If I'm Here... What Am I Doing Over There?" story takes place on April Fools Day.
name: The Phantom Touch of Death! / If I'm Here... What Am I Doing Over There?

description:
Superman's Greatest Blunder!

No Description

The Boy Who Broke Supergirl's Heart!

Meet Gary Sparks, the campus casanova who loves them and leaves them! If ever a cat deserved to get his lumps, it's this two-timing, egotistic phoney. But, believe it or not, Gary turns out to be... The Boy Who Broke Supergirl's Heart!
name: Superman's Greatest Blunder; The Boy Who Broke Supergirl's Heart!

description:
1. Achilles Vs. Superman (Superman vs John Achilles / written by Edmond Hamilton)
  2. The Wind- Up Toys of Peril (Superman vs Prankster)
  3. Shorty (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  4. Boys Who Never Give Up (full text article)
  5. Miss Metropolis of 1950 (Superman vs. Happy Ferris)

"Girls! Girls! Girls! How dangerous is your job? If you're beautiful and brave, you may be chosen 'Miss Metropolis of 1950'"
name: Miss Metropolis of 1950

description:
1. Professor Lois Lane (Lois Lane, Superman / written by Alvin Schwartz) -- 2. The Isle of Giant Insects (Superman / written by Edmond Hamilton) -- 3. How We Multiply Our Strength (full text article) -- 4. The Free-For-All Crimes (Superman vs Prankster / written by William Woolfolk)

"Shhh! Don't tip her off--but there's plenty of action and excitement ahead in her role of 'Professor Lois Lane!'"
name: Professor Lois Lane

description:
1. Cover by Jose Luis Garcia Lopez and Bob Oksner.
  2. "One of Our Phantoms is Missing!" written by Cary Bates, penciled by Curt Swan, inked by Tex Blaisdell and colored by Jerry Serpe.
  3. "...Another Masterful Missive from Our Publisher!!" 3/4 page text piece by Jenette Kahn.
  4. "DC Profiles #4 Murray Boltinoff" 1/4 text piece by Mike Gold.
  5. "The Long Weekend" A "The Private Life of Clark Kent" story written by Bill Kunkel, penciled by John Calnan, inked by Tex Blaisdell and colored by Anthony Tollin.

Notes:

  • This issue contains the Hostess Superhero Ad, Batman in "The Whole World's Upside Down".
  • The Editor's Note in "One of Our Phantoms is Missing!" erroneously mentions Superman #396-399. It should have been Superman #296-299.
name: One of Our Phantoms is Missing / The Long Weekend

description:
Superman takes in a mysterious boy with superpowers who crash landed on Earth.

  1. "The Boy From Outer Space!" (Superman, Batman and Robin) written by Edmond Hamilton. Reprinted World's Finest Comics #170, World's Finest Comics Archives #2 and Showcase Presents: World's Finest #1.
  2. "Lem n' Lime" gag strip by Henry Boltinoff.
  3. "The Indian Cannoneers" (Tomahawk)
  4. "Varsity Vic" gag strip by Henry Boltinoff.
  5. "World At Your Fingertips" full text article.
  6. "Marauders from the Deep" (Green Arrow)
  7. "Wanted: A Teen-Age Code" public service message written by Jack Schiff.

"Look! There go Batman and Robin-- and Superman with his new junior partner, Skyboy!"
name: The Boy from Outer Space!

description: Overview The Beast Wars—a timelost series of conflicts on Earth: heroic Maximals pitted against evil Predacons. The action steps up into an even higher gear as Magmatron turns his attention to fulfilling his original (Tri-Predacus Council-approved) mission objective: capture Megatron and return him to Cybertron for trial. Does that mean he’s prepared to just let Razorbeast and his Maximal militia be? Of course not. Not now that Ravage is on the case!

A scientist's machine accidentally gives both Robin and Victor Danning, a villain, Superman's super-intelligence!

  1. "The Boss of Batman and Superman" (Superman, Batman and Robin) written by Bill Finger, penciled by Dick Sprang and inked by Stan Kaye.
  2. "Dexter the Cab Driver" gag strip by Henry Boltinoff.
  3. "The Raid of the Vulture-Man!" (Green Arrow & Speedy vs Vulture Man) written by Unknown, penciled and inked by George Papp.
  4. "Movie Mirth" gag strip.
  5. "The Dog's Distant Days" two page full text article written by Unknown.
  6. "The Militia Without Muskets!" (Tomahawk & Dan Hunter) written by Unknown, penciled and inked by Fred Ray.

Notes:

  • Boomerang Arrow, Flare Arrow, Firecracker Arrows, Net Arrow and Cable Arrow (from the Arrowplane) used.

Robin becomes a Super-Boy Wonder..."

Robin: No, no, Superman! You get rid of the flood the way I told you, while Batman goes after those crooks in the sub!
name: The Boss of Batman and Superman / The Raid of the Vulture-Man! / The Militia Without Muskets!

description: The Beast Wars–a timelost series of conflicts on Earth that pitted heroic Maximals against evil Predacons. The searing mini-series draws to a close, with pitched battles and desperate last stands on two fronts. While Razorbeast stands alone against the all-powerful Magmatron, desperate to prevent his return to Cybertron, so his fellow Maximals must somehow survive the onslaught of Ravage and his massed Predacon forces and get a warning back to the future. No happy endings are guaranteed!

1. Courtship, Kryptonian Style! (Lois Lane, Superman, Lana Lang, Superman Emergenct Squad, Don-EL, Sylvia / written by Leo Dorfman : story continued from Lois Lane #76) -- 2. Superman's Forbidden Room (Lois, Superman, Perry White : reprinted from Lois Lane #2) -- 3. Cap's Hobby Center (activity page by Henry Boltinoff)

"Featuring Superman as the Immovable Man and Lois as the Irresistible Woman!"

Superman: Lois! Those bullets are bouncing off you! You're super-- like me!

Lois Lane: Right, Superman! Now do we get married?
name: Courtship, Kryptonian Style

description:
1. Cover by Wayne Boring and Kurt Schaffenberger.
  2. "The Witch of Metropolis" Reprinted from Superman's Girl Friend Lois Lane #1.
  3. "Lois Lane -- Convict" Reprinted from Superman's Girl Friend Lois Lane #6.
  4. "The Six Lives of Lois Lane!" Reprinted from Action Comics #198.
  5. "The Mad Woman of Metropolis!" Reprinted from Superman's Girl Friend Lois Lane #26.
  6. "Lois Lane's X-Ray Vision!" Reprinted from Superman's Girl Friend Lois Lane #22.
  7. "The Ghost of Lois Lane" Reprinted from Superman #129.
  8. "Lois Lane's Darkest Secret!" Reprinted from Superman's Girl Friend Lois Lane #25.
  9. "The Fattest Girl in Metropolis" Reprinted from Superman's Girl Friend Lois Lane #5.
  10. "Cap's Hobby Hints How to do it Better" activity page by Henry Boltinoff.

Notes:

  • This "80 pg. Giant G39" is a collection of reprints, mostly from earlier Lois Lane issues, but a few are from Superman related titles.

"The Madwoman of Metropolis! ; Lois' witchcraft curse! ; Lois Lane-- convict! ; The ghost of Lois Lane! ; Lois Lane's X-ray vision!"
name: A Collection of Lois' Greatest Shockers!

description:
1. Jimmy Olsen's Martian Pal (Jimmy Olsen, Superman, Perry White / written by Otto Binder)
  2. Do You Know How to Be a Good Baby-Sitter? (public service message by Buzzy / written by Jack Schiff)
  3. Jimmy Olsen's Forgotten Adventure (Jimmy Olsen / written by Otto Binder)
  4. Little Pete (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  5. Shorty (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  6. How to be a Weather Expert (full text article by Jack Miller)
  7. Jungle Jimmy Olsen (Jimmy Olsen, Superman / written by Otto Binder)
name: Jungle Jimmy Olsen ; How to Predict the Weather

description: The Beast Wars–a timelost series of conflicts on Earth: heroic Maximals pitted against evil Predacons. Deep cover agent Razorbeast is on the run, he and his new Maximal militia hunted by Magmatron and his superior Predacon force. Razorbeast’s only viable play is to get a warning back to Cybertron, and to do that he needs a Transwarp Signal Booster. Where do you find one of those on prehistoric Earth? In Ravage’s downed Transwarp cruiser, that’s where!

name: Mother Goose And Nursery Rhyme Comics

description: This is a big one...there's an event that will shake the girls right to their foundations! All this plus bonus photo and art features, too! Never have schoolgirl adventures been this much fun!
name: Aye, Robot!

description:
1. Miracle in the Wildwood
  2. 2. Wonderful Journey of Kris Kyro
name: Santa Claus Funnies

description:
1. "Frozen Gold"

2. "Mystery of the Swamp"
name: Donald Duck in Frozen Gold

description:
Who is the Masked Superman. Could it be... nah, it couldn't! 
 
... Could it?
name: The Grappler of Steel

description:
1. Cover by Neal Adams.
  2. "Alias Super-Thief!" written by Otto Binder, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by Jack Abel.
  3. "Super-Turtle" gag strip by Henry Boltinoff.
  4. "No Mercy for Supergirl!" written by Leo Dorfman, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger.
name: Alias Super-Thief! / No Mercy for Supergirl!

description:
Overview                      

Batman takes on the villain you've been waiting for: The Joker! One is the Heroic Dark Knight…the other is The Agent of Chaos. Batman's oldest enemy has killed one person too many , and Batman makes a new vow: "Tonight, The Joker dies by my hand!" For all the crimes The Joker has commited, Batman seeks retribution. Will the Dark Knight finally cross the ultimate line between Hero and Vigilante?
 

Spoilers                                

Batman has just found that his friend Thomas Elliot has just been killed by the Joker.  Batman goes in to a rage and starts to beat the Joker.  The Joker tries to convince Batman that it really was not him.  Through all of this Batman is thinking of all the things the Joker has done to him.  How he killed Jason Todd and how he parylzed Barbra Gordan.  When Batman is about to kill the Joker, James Gordan comes to save Batman from doing something he would have regretted, and becoming the very evil he vowed to fight.  He spares the Jokers life.  At the end of it all you see Two-Face in bandages.
name: Hush Chapter Seven : The Joke

description: A new arc of "Hush" begins! A perfect evening out on the town for Bruce and Selina takes a turn for the deadly when Harley Quinn hits Gotham City. And if Harley's back, can the Joker be far behind? Just when you thought Loeb & Lee might have run out of twists, wait until you read the last page!
name: Hush Chapter Six: The Opera

description: The unpredictable Black Mask forms an uneasy alliance with the Red Hood! But can these two uncompromising masked men truly cooperate? Or will this team-up make the streets of Gotham run red with bad blood? Either way, it's sure to spell trouble for the Batman as Jason Todd kidnaps The Joker and someone drops into Bludhaven, having leaving Atomic Destruction!
name: All They Do Is Watch Us Kill, Part 2 of 3

description: Batman is after the Grotesk killer now and picks up the trail at the research and development division of Omnimed.  Attempting to gather information on the late Mr. Wayne Franklin, Batman finds himself not the only one after the much sought Mimic-copy, as Johnny Karaoke and his Geisha Grrls are there to retrieve the device.  Along the way Grotesk stops in just to make this visit all the more difficult for the Dark Knight.  Yakuza and Russian mobster involvement compel the Caped Crusader then to speculate on who the Grotesk killer is, and why Dr. Amina Franklin is in grave danger for the secrets he is certain she is keeping.
name: Grotesk, Part 2

description: Bringing heat upon Perun and his thugs, Grotesk attempts to strike a deal with the Russian mobsters by having them meet with him at the old Gotham City Opera House.  It is yet another scandalous trick as Grotesk has secretly already invited Johnny Karaoke and his Geisha Grrls to the entertainment establishment in the attempt to get both factions of gangsters to kill each other in the bloody attempt to take the Mimic-prototype.  Batman attempts to save the day only to find Grotesk putting others in danger allows him to make a break for freedom once more.  The Dark Knight then decides in the fiery aftermath to attempt an alternative solution in linking Grotesk and Wayne Franklin as the same culprit.
name: Grotesk, Part 3

description: For someone who had to suffer his parents' murder as a child, having a family of his own should be a dream come true for Bruce Wayne. But then, he probably never envisioned a child like Damian. Neglected by his mother, and raised by Ra's al Ghul's League of Assassins , the boy is incredibly arrogant, and dangerously skilled for someone so young. Unsure if he is truly Damian's father, but unable to deny the possibility, Bruce takes the boy back to Gotham with him after Talia leaves. For perhaps the first time in his life, Damian isn't surrounded by people who will obey him. When he sees that Bruce won't simply let him run free, he decides to prove himself to his father. But Damian finds that there is an obstacle in his path... an adopted son who aids in his fathers' war on crime, Tim Drake . And Damian knows only one way to deal with obstacles... very directly.
name: Batman & Son, Part 3: Wonderboys

description: Oracle delves into the mystery of Misfit while Lady Blackhawk and Huntress hash out their differences!
name: Shark Attack

description: The sensational 2-part story "Mademoiselle Marie" begins! Long before World War II, a legendary French spy network was born - and now a kidnapping in Africa has turned the Mademoiselle Marie legacy against its latest standard-bearer, the Black Queen's Knight!
name: La Vie En Sang

description: "Mademoiselle Marie" concludes! Will Black Queen's Knight get her target safely out of Bialya, or will she become the latest Mademoiselle Marie to be laid to eternal rest?
name: La Vie En Sang, Part Deux

description: In Part 2 of “Jack Be Nimble,” featuring guest art by David Hahn (BITE CLUB), Jack continues to ride the Hollywood high of his new slickster lifestyle, losing sight of the enemies he’s made along the way. And the one thing you can count on in Tinseltown is that there’s always someone waiting for you to fall — and ready to stab you in the back on your way down.
name: Jack Be Nimble: Part Two of Two

description: The House, Rain Harper and the ghostly Juris are back, and so is the sickly compelling allure of people's secrets. What horrifying secret in Rain's past is coming back to haunt her?

It's a typical day back in the world from which the inhabitants of Fabletown escaped, full of war and tyranny, not to mention taxes. But in the midst of all the conquering and the slaying comes a mysterious masked man on a quest to find the woman in red he believed was killed centuries ago.
name: Death & Taxes: Chapter One of Homelands

description: Part 2 of a Boy Blue story, in which he continues his dark and dangerous quest to find his lost love through lands wrecked and ravaged by the Adversary’s evil will. But Blue will stop at nothing to find his lost love, even when the enemies set before him grow increasingly more deadly.
name: The Saint George Syndrome: Chapter Two of Homelands

description: A recap of volume 1 indicates this series takes place 3 years later. The series itself will say 2 years.

volume.name: G.I. Joe vs. The Transformers, Vol. II

description:
1. Cover by Jose Luis Garcia Lopez and Bob Oksner.
  2. "The Night Superman was Buried in Boot Hill!" (Superman) written by Cary Bates, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by Tex Blaisdell. Superman vs Terra Man.
  3. "And Now... We Interrupt this Comic to bring You a Word from Your New Publisher..." A one page text piece by Jenette Kahn.
  4. "Clark Kent's Lonely Christmas!" A (The Private Life of Clark Kent) story written by Bob Rozakis, penciled by John Calnan and inked by Tex Blaisdell.

Notes:

  • This issue contains the Hostess Superhero Ad, Aquaman and Twinkies Cakes in "That Dirty Beach".
  • The story "Clark Kent's Lonely Christmas!" takes place on December 24, 1977 and it continues in The Superman Family #182.
name: The Night Superman was Buried in Boot Hill! / Clark Kent's Lonely Christmas!

description:
1. Cover by Neal Adams.
  2. "Terra-Man at Nine O'Clock!" (Superman) written by Cary Bates, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by Tex Blaisdell. Superman vs Terra Man and viewers can watch it on TV!
  3. "Daily Planet" Volume 76 Issue 31 the week of November 29, 1976 edited by Bob Rozakis and lettered by Typeset. Featuring Richard Dragon battling a student of the immortal Bruce Lee. Plus Lola Barnett's Comicsworld.
  4. "My Son, the Orphan!" A (Close-Up: Morgan Edge) story written by Martin Pasko, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by Frank McLaughlin. A brief origin of Morgan Edge.

Notes:

  • This issue contains the Hostess Superhero Ad, Wonder Woman and Cup Cakes in "The Maltese Cup Cake".
  • King Kong only appears on television.
  • It was revealed in "My Son, the Orphan!" that Morgan Edge's real name is Morris Edelstein.

  • The first appearance of the DC Bullet logo.
name: Terra-Man at Nine O'Clock! / My Son, the Orphan!

description:
2008 Preview

Forging Iron Man: interviews with cast members Robert Downey Jr., Gwyneth Paltrow and Terrence Howard and director Jon Favreau Q&A;

"Crisis" Counseling: Final Crisis with Grant Morrison and J.G. Jones;

Secret Invasion;

Incredible Hulk: Louis Leterrier Q&A;

Ultimates 3;

Dark Knight:Christopher Nolan Q&A;

Artists to Watch;

Captain America;

Lost Season 4;

Battlestar Galactica;

Spider-Man: Brand New Day;

Alan Moore: Q&A;

Ultimates Mark Millar & Bryan Hitch's "FF" Team-Up;

Terminator: Sarah Connor Chronicles;

Greatest X-Men Events;

Warren Ellis;
name: 2008 Preview Spectacular!

description:
1. Cover by Bob Oksner.
  2. "Stop it, Superman -- You're Wrecking the World!" (Superman) written by Gerry Conway, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by Tex Blaisdell.
  3. "Daily Planet" Volume 76 Issue 26 the week of October 25, 1976 edited by Bob Rozakis and lettered by Typeset. Featuring Kamandi. Plus Lola Barnett exclusive interview with Joe Orlando.
  4. "A Superman's Best Friend is His Superdog!" (Krypto and Mr. Myxzptlk) written by Bob Rozakis, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by Tex Blaisdell.

Notes:

  • This issue contains the Hostess Superhero Ad, Batman and Robin in "The Muse".
  • During the 6pm newscast Clark Kent mentions the appearance of a new superhero appearing in the slum sections of Metropolis. This same superhero is battling against the 100. The mysterious superhero is none other then Black Lightning.

  • The last appearance of the "DC The Line of Super-Stars" logo.
name: Stop It, Superman -- You're Wrecking the World! / A Superman's Best Friend is His Superdog!

description:
1. The Testing of Superman (Superman vs The Professor)
  2. Superman's Sweetheart (Superman vs Whitey Nelson / written by William Woolfolk)
  3. The Story Behind History (full text article)
  4. Three Supermen From Krypton (Superman vs Kizo, Mala, and U-Ban) - A tremendous quake rocks Metropolis, threatening to topple all the buildings. After Superman manages to save the city, he discovers that the shockwave was caused by a rocketship crash. Aboard were three Kryptonian criminals who were exiled to space for attempting to conquer Krypton. Now they are intent on conquering the Earth. But how can Superman stop not one, but three foes with powers equivalent to his own?
name: The 3 Supermen from Krypton

description: 1. The Babe of Steel (Superman vs Prankster / written by William Woolfolk) -- 2. The Last Days of Superman (Superman / written by William Woolfolk) -- 3. Heavy Birds (full text article) -- 4. Bebe (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff) -- 5. The Machine That Played Cupid (Superman / written by Alvin Schwartz)
name: The Babe of Steel

description:
1. Perry Como, I Love You (Superman, Lois Lane, Perry Como : "Can even Superman blast Lois Lane's super-crush on super-crooner Perry Como?" / written by Bill Woolfolk)
  2. The City Under the Sea (Superman vs Hajar / written by Alvin Schwartz)
  3. Music March (full text article)
  4. Varsity Vic (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  5. Clark Kent's Twin (Superman vs Skinhead / written by Alvin Schwartz)
name: Perry Como, I Love You

description:
OverviewDark Horse Comics and the Conan team are proud to introduce new series artist Tomás Giorello! Best known for the powerful fantasy illustrations for Wizards of the Coast and other prominent publishers, Giorello has also made his mark on comics, contributing to a slew of Star Wars titles. Now, he lends his dynamic pencils to the barbarian, joining writer Timothy Truman as he takes Conan from the boisterous "Rogues in the House" to an adaptation of the darker Howard fragment "The Hand of Nergal."

Conan has escaped the city with his head intact, but little else to show for his labors. Little does he know that a piece of his past still follows him, stalking the Cimmerian with the patience of the grave.
name: The Spawn of Nergal

description: Humanity has been drafted - turning Presidents into foot soldiers, healers into killers, and ordinary people into figures of destiny. A number of Earth's draftees embark on their first, harrowing training mission. Amidst all this, the world gets its first terrifying glimpse of the approaching enemy!
name: The Crucible

description: The conclusion to the mini-series. "The Salem Seven" enact the arcane rites of their annual reunion. But what begins as an expedition into the creepy woods of Salem to disavow "Satan," ends as an arresting excursion into the past of childhood friends with lingering and deadly secrets. What happened in the woods a decade ago? Who is the betrayer intent on escaping their secrets even at the cost of the lives of the Salem Seven? And how can Rain unlock her past to save herself and her closest friends from the deadly Juris haunting the new East-coast House of Secrets?

1. Superboy's Advisor! (Superboy / written by Jerry Coleman) -- 2. The Demon Reporter! (Superboy, Lana lang, Ma and pa Kent) -- 3. Start the Day Off Right! (public service message by Buzzy / written by Jack Schiff) -- 4. Varsity Vic (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff) -- 5. Johnny Appleseed! (bio) -- 6. Paging Young Mr. America (full text article)-- 7. The Amazing Elephant Boy from Smallville! (Superboy, Lana) -- 8. Peg (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
name: The Amazing Elephant Boy From Smallville

description:
1. The Silent Doom! (Superboy, Lana Lang)
  2. Shorty (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  3. When Superboy Couldn't Fly! (Superboy vs Blimp Beagle / written by William Woolfolk)
  4. Peg (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  5. Big Game at Our Own Back Door (full text article by Jack Miller)
  6. Special Brotherhood Week Quiz (public service message by Buzzy / written by Jack Schiff)
  7. Professor Eureka (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  8. His Majesty King Superboy! (Superboy vs Richard Bayne)

Pa Kent: Who ever thought our boy, Clark, would someday be a king!
name: His Majesty, King Superboy

description:
New York City: It’s the roaring 20s and America’s great metropolis has become the nexus of high society culture, cutting edge industry and perhaps the most shocking crime wave in our country’s history. Known for its sinister and treacherous underworld, there’s a new power waking up the city that never sleeps. Its name... John "The Hand" Smith.

The Nickname is a given. An outcast and an orphan, Smith’s massive right hand is nearly twice as large as his left, and when push comes to shove, you’d pity anyone that’s gets in his way. Smith’s only friends in the world are a fellow orphan and low-rent black gangster nicknamed Bootsy, and a Asian femme fatale known as Ring–a-Ling. In a world of crime, passion, and a touch of the fantastic, they will attempt to change organized crime… or die trying.

From two of New York's favorite sons, independent director Edward Burns (Brothers McMullen, Saving Private Ryan) and comics' legend Jimmy Palmiotti (Painkiller Jane, Monolith).

This superbly evocative graphic novella by the award-winning Norwegian cartoonist Jason (his first appearance in the English language) starts off as a melancholy childhood memoir and then, with a shocking twist midway through, becomes the summary of lives lived, wasted, and lost. (Imagine a version of Stand by Me in which not all of the kids outrace the train.) Like Art Spiegelman did with Maus, Jason utilizes anthropomorphic stylizations to reach deeper, more general truths, and to create elegantly minimalist panels whose emotional depth charge comes as an even greater shock. His sparse dialogue, dark wit, and supremely bold use of "jump-cuts" from one scene to the next (sometimes spanning a number of years) make Hey, Wait... a surprising and engaging debut. Love and Rockets co-creator Gilbert Hernandez calls this one of the best graphic novels ever.

person_credits.name: Jason
person_credits.role: writer, penciler, letterer, inker, colorist, cover

description:
1. Cover by Neal Adams.
  2. "The Bride of Titanman!" written by Richard Hughes, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger. (Lois Lane, Superman, Jimmy Olsen, Perry White (in a dream)
  3. "Checkmate for Lois!" written by E. Nelson Bridwell, penciled and inked by Kurt Schaffenberger. (Lois, Superman, Lana Lang, Jimmy, Perry, Lewis Lang) A chess related adventure.

Lois Lane: Superman, stop my wedding to Titanman! I just found out the terrible secret his mask is hiding!

Superman: Serves you right for choosing him over me, Lois. Marry him!
name: The Bride of Titanman! / Checkmate for Lois!
